title: What are some ways to describe characters of color? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll do my best to give you advice, though in the end you have to honor your style. Hopefully you can do that without going through all kinds of contortions. If you’re not used to including characters of color in your work, you may find it challenging at first. It’ll take practice, like everything else. Repetition of a character’s ethnicity when they’re an unnamed character can be a problem when you don’t use names or other monikers. What do I mean by a moniker? You ‘nickname’ unnamed characters so that the reader can keep track of who is who without having to repeat physical descriptions. For example, if I have an assault going on in an alley, I might nickname the assaulting characters Bottle Man, Knife Woman and Boxer Kid. Or whatever. A moniker is far preferable than drawing unnatural attention to ethnicity. But maybe you’re less concerned about repeatedly calling an unnamed character a black man or a Hispanic woman and more interested in the initial description. It’s a cliché and somewhat tacky to describe people in terms of food. It’s not only overused to describe someone as hot chocolate or cafe au lait, those may have racist overtones, just like calling someone a ‘red Indian’ (shudder) or a ‘yellow Oriental.’ BTW, Oriental is for objects, not people. Asian people are Asian, and hopefully if you have an Asian character, you’ll be describing them more specifically, since Asia covers a lot more ground than the United States, and the United States has quite the collection of cultures. If a description has been used since before the 70’s, chances are that you’ll want to avoid it. So what does that leave? Natural objects, such as earth, metals, woods. It’s easy to fall back on the ‘normal’ ones like bronze and mahogany, so you’ll want to spend some time really thinking on this. Presumably you have a setting, right? Bring that setting in. “He reminded me of that summer when the shadows of vast clouds played over the fields, turning them a mysterious color that was neither gold nor brown but a rich color in between, and his hair was like the deepest shade where I would hide and fan myself while watching the river flow by.” “She looked like she ought to be driving a red Lamborghini in a white dress, her dark skin as perfect as a supermodel’s, her auburn-toned hair cut short and neat in a style that I always wished I could pull off.” If you don’t write long-winded, you could address what you think is the most important aspect of your character from the beginning. Try not to make that first thing their skin color. It should be more important that they’re physically imposing, or small and delicate, or they’re laughing and carefree, graceful, or you notice their clothes, or that they’re carrying a weapon. And remember, it will be your character noticing these things, so whatever the character notices first will be what the reader will assume is the most important detail to that character. If it’s always skin color, that may suggest some unpleasant things about that character that you don’t intend to suggest. Beyond these suggestions, it’s hard to give more specific advice because it really will depend on your style. Everyone is on their own to develop their own style. Don’t be afraid to write “he was the only black man at the Vietnamese restaurant.” It’s shorthand and inoffensive. If you’re new to including a diverse cast of characters, you might check out the following links. The first is to an Atlantic article on appropriation that’s a good starting point. It’s not the last word on the subject for sure, though, so don’t become complacent. The second link leads to annoying movie clichés. Within that list are quite a few that point out plot points that turn on racist assumptions and stereotypes. The Dos and Don'ts of Cultural Appropriation What are some of the most annoying movie clichés? Finally, if you’re a writer who’s serious about this subject, you should visit author Steve Barnes’ website. This subject comes up fairly often on his blog, as do other topics related to diversity, representation, and writing ethically. Steven Barnes I hope this helps!

It’s not offensive to describe skin color as a physical trait, any more than it is to describe eye color, and it is as relevant as any other trait. In fact, to *my* mind it is racist to shy away from fundamental descriptions out of fear that drawing attention to skin color will somehow be offensive. It is part of our appearance, as relevant as anything else one might notice when looking at a person. Ignoring it is dishonest. And I don’t agree with the food restriction. Snow White had skin the color of cream and lips like ripe cherries. It doesn’t “objectify” a person to liken his or her coloring to a familiar image. Also some food words like cocoa, chocolate, and mocha are legitimate color names. I have heard all of those used by black actors, and black characters in TV shows, to describe other black people. Mahgony, olive (which in skin tone means golden, not green) , golden, bronze, ruddy, and copper are all good descriptions, as are color names : brown, sienna, umber….however you should assume that some readers will not know technical color names. “Fair” is the traditional term for a pale complextion with pink undertones. Pale also works. There is a skin color in one part of Africa that is actually deep charcoal, quite dramatic, so actual black skin is not impossible, but make sure that’s what you mean. I don’t personally have an issue with referring to race, if that’s what characters would notice. “A tall, good looking black man entered the room” should not offend anyone (though it gives us no particular clue about his coloring.) Freedom from racism does not mean we don’t notice physical differences between people. As a side note, most readers will assume a character is white unless you indicate otherwise, especially in fantasy novels. I’ve been on writer panels where authors shared stories about fans and even cover artists rendering characters of color as white; every writer seemed to have one (including me). If you want your characters to be non-white, don’t be too subtle. I’ll see if I can’t dig up some of my own descriptions of dark skinned characters as examples when I get to my real computer. Regarding the person questioning how often you should mention that an African American character is African American…er, once. Skin color, like eye color, weight, or height, might be repeated if there’s a moment when it makes a nice image, but there’s no reason to assume that if you don’t keep repeating a racial cue your readers will forget it. ADDED: Okay, here are the descriptive intros for my three of my dark-skinned characters, so you can see how I personally handled it. ——————— TOSHIDA: Has been active in the story for about five pages, among people who know him well and would not take note of his appearance. This is from the POV of newly arrived visitors: Two oil lamps cast dim golden light about the room and its occupants; its hue lent an eerie cast to the Regent’s dark skin, like that of an ancient bronze statue.  SONONDRA RA: Next to enter was a figure whose surface glittered with a thousand rainbow gems. Lean, lithe, and dark-skinned, Sonondra Ra wore as little clothing as protocol permitted, in order that the sensors which studded her skin might have as maximum data input. They glittered like diamonds as she moved, tiny contacts embedded in her cocoa skin.  DEVON: My protag met him online; this is their first live meeting. I’m not sure why it surprised me that Devon turned out to be black. He was a good-looking guy, with dark skin and long, lean features. He was also tall—very tall—and his height was all in his legs, giving him the look of a marathon runner. So…that’s my own approach…simple, matter of fact, unself-conscious. Just tell the reader what the characters would notice, in the language that describes it best.
